Grammar of Dashboards - Conceptual Framework

The Analogy: ggplot2â€™s Grammar of Graphics

Just as ggplot2 revolutionized data visualization by providing a grammar of graphics, dashboardr aims to provide a grammar of dashboards.

ggplot2â€™s Core Components:

  1. Data - The dataset
  2. Aesthetics - Mappings from data to visual properties
  3. Geometries - Visual representations (points, lines, bars)
  4. Scales - Control how data maps to aesthetics
  5. Facets - Split plots into subplots
  6. Coordinates - The coordinate system
  7. Themes - Non-data visual elements

Grammar of Dashboards - Core Components

1. Data Layer

The foundation - what youâ€™re visualizing

dashboardr has: - âœ… Multi-dataset support - âœ… Data deduplication across pages - âœ… Automatic data path resolution - âœ… Filter-based data subsets

Could be enhanced: - ğŸ”„ Data transformations in-place - ğŸ”„ Dynamic data loading - ğŸ”„ Data connections (databases, APIs)

2. Visualization Layer

The â€œgeometriesâ€ of dashboards

dashboardr has: - âœ… Multiple viz types (histogram, timeline, stackedbar, heatmap, bar) - âœ… Composable visualizations (create_viz() %>% add_viz()) - âœ… Type-specific parameters - âœ… Defaults + overrides pattern - âœ… Custom function-based visualizations

This is strong! The piping workflow is very grammar-like.

3. Hierarchy/Grouping Layer

The â€œfacetsâ€ of dashboards - organizing related content

dashboardr has: - âœ… Tabgroups with automatic nesting - âœ… Tree-based hierarchy (visible via print()) - âœ… Custom tab labels - âœ… Filter-based automatic grouping - âœ… Flexible nesting levels

This is UNIQUE to dashboardr! Most dashboard tools require manual nesting.

4. Layout Layer

How things are arranged spatially

dashboardr has: - âœ… Pages (top-level containers) - âœ… Cards (content containers) - âœ… Card rows (horizontal arrangement) - âœ… Quartoâ€™s column/row orientation

Could be enhanced: - ğŸ”„ Responsive layouts (mobile/desktop) - ğŸ”„ Grid systems - ğŸ”„ Dynamic sizing based on content - ğŸ”„ Drag-and-drop arrangement

5. Navigation Layer

How users move through the dashboard

dashboardr has: - âœ… Navbar (top navigation) - âœ… Sidebar (side navigation) - âœ… Sidebar groups - âœ… Navbar menus (dropdowns) - âœ… Landing pages - âœ… Icon support

This is comprehensive!

6. Styling/Theming Layer

The â€œthemesâ€ of dashboards

dashboardr has: - âœ… Tabset themes (pills, modern, classic, etc.) - âœ… Custom SCSS support - âœ… Color palettes - âœ… Custom tabset colors - âœ… Loading overlays

Could be enhanced: - ğŸ”„ Global theme system (not just tabsets) - ğŸ”„ Color scales - ğŸ”„ Typography control - ğŸ”„ Brand presets

7. Interactivity Layer

User-driven exploration

dashboardr has: - âš ï¸ Filters (limited - pre-defined at build time) - âœ… Tabs (user-driven navigation)

Could be enhanced: - ğŸ”„ Dynamic filters (Shiny-like) - ğŸ”„ Linked selections - ğŸ”„ Drill-downs - ğŸ”„ Tooltips - ğŸ”„ Crossfiltering

Note: dashboardr generates static Quarto dashboards, so true interactivity requires JavaScript/Shiny.

8. Composition Layer

Combining elements

dashboardr has: - âœ… + operator for viz collections - âœ… combine_viz() function - âœ… %>% piping throughout - âœ… Defaults inheritance - âœ… Automatic merging of labels

This is excellent! Very composable.

9. Generation/Rendering Layer

From specification to output

dashboardr has: - âœ… Automatic QMD generation - âœ… Quarto YAML configuration - âœ… Incremental builds - âœ… Preview mode - âœ… Progress tracking - âœ… Error messages with suggestions

Very polished!

Summary: dashboardrâ€™s Grammar

Core Principles (Grammar-like)

  1. Layering - Build dashboards by adding layers

    dashboard <- create_dashboard() %>%
  add_page() %>%
  add_page()

  2. Composition - Combine visualizations naturally

    viz1 + viz2  # or combine_viz(viz1, viz2)

  3. Defaults + Overrides - Set once, override when needed

    create_viz(type = "histogram", color = "blue") %>%
  add_viz(x_var = "age") %>%              # uses blue
  add_viz(x_var = "income", color = "red") # overrides to red

  4. Declarative - Describe what you want, not how to build it

    add_viz(type = "histogram", x_var = "age", filter = ~ wave == 1)
# dashboardr figures out the structure

  5. Hierarchical - Automatic organization based on tabgroups

    tabgroup = "demographics/age/item1"  # auto-nests

What Makes dashboardr Unique?

1. Automatic Hierarchy Building

Most dashboard tools require manual nesting. dashboardr infers structure from tabgroup paths and filter parameters.

2. Tree Visualization

The print() methods show the actual structure being generated - pedagogical and debugging-friendly.

3. Filter-Aware Grouping

Automatically groups visualizations by their filter expressions.

4. Piping-First Design

Everything is pipeable, making complex dashboards readable.

5. Static + Fast

Generates static HTML (via Quarto), so itâ€™s fast, hostable anywhere, and doesnâ€™t require a server.

Missing Pieces (Future Grammar Components?)

1. Scales (like ggplot2)

  • Define color scales globally
  • Coordinate scales across visualizations
  • Custom scale transformations

2. Annotations

  • Text overlays on visualizations
  • Reference lines
  • Highlights

3. Computed Variables

  • Create variables on-the-fly
  • Statistical transformations
  • Aggregations at dashboard-level

4. Responsive Design

  • Mobile layouts
  • Conditional rendering based on screen size

5. State Management

  • User preferences
  • Saved filters
  • Bookmarkable states

Pedagogical Framing

For Vignettes:

Introduction: > â€œJust as ggplot2 provides a grammar of graphics for creating visualizations, > dashboardr provides a grammar of dashboards for organizing and presenting them. > > This grammar consists of: > - Data - what youâ€™re visualizing > - Visualizations - how you show it > - Hierarchy - how you organize it > - Layout - how you arrange it > - Navigation - how users explore it > - Styling - how it looks > > By combining these elements through a fluent piping interface, you can build > complex dashboards that are both powerful and maintainable.â€

Key Message: â€œPrint your viz objects to see the tree structure! This reveals how dashboardr interprets your specifications and builds the hierarchy.â€

Examples for Vignettes

Show the Tree!

# Create a simple visualization collection
viz <- create_viz(type = "histogram") %>%
  add_viz(x_var = "age", tabgroup = "demographics", title = "Age") %>%
  add_viz(x_var = "income", tabgroup = "demographics", title = "Income") %>%
  add_viz(x_var = "score", tabgroup = "performance", title = "Score")

# Print it to see the structure!
print(viz)

# Output shows:
# â”œâ”€ demographics
# â”‚  â”œâ”€ Age
# â”‚  â””â”€ Income
# â””â”€ performance
#    â””â”€ Score

This makes the hierarchy visible and understandable.

Conclusion

dashboardr already embodies many principles of a â€œgrammar of dashboardsâ€:

âœ… Composable - Build complex from simple
âœ… Declarative - Describe the what, not the how
âœ… Layered - Add components incrementally
âœ… Hierarchical - Automatic organization
âœ… Pipeable - Fluent, readable syntax
âœ… Inspectable - Print methods reveal structure

What could enhance the grammar: - Global scales/themes - More layout control - Annotations - Computed variables - True interactivity (would require Shiny backend)

The foundation is strong! The vignettes should emphasize this grammatical approach.
